h3. Issue Summary

Event reminder notifications in WATCHED CALENDARS do not consistently fire. When adding a single user to the 'WHO' section when adding a new EVENT, these reminders fire off intermittently. When adding multiple users in the 'WHO' section, these EVENT reminders never fire off.

(i) NOTE: WATCHING the CALENDAR means that the user has ADDED the CALENDAR to their CALENDAR (user logs in, selects CALENDARS at the top, adds the newly created CALENDAR and turns on reminders for that calendar).

Users that are simply watching the SPACE or PAGE that has an embedded CALENDAR *only* will NOT receive EVENT reminders when added to an EVENT on this CALENDAR.

(i) Tested using Confluence 7.10.0 with TC 7.0.17. Some admins may also see the issue in Confluence 7.11.1 with TC 7.0.17.
 # Install Confluence (latest) with TC (latest).
 # User A creates a CALENDAR for a space. Setup the EVENT type reminder for 10 minutes (same with Custom EVENT types).
 # User B logs in, navigates to CALENDARS, adds the new CALENDAR to their CALENDAR.
 # User C does the same as User B.
 # User A adds User B and C to the 'Who' section of the EVENT, both of which should be WATCHING the CALENDAR.
 # Set an EVENT for 15 minutes in the future, end an hour later. Set a description.
 # After saving the EVENT, you should see an reminder email fire after 5 minutes (not an add user or add event email).

The EVENT _reminder_ is sent out to all who users who are WATCHING the CALENDAR and were added to the EVENT 10 minutes before the EVENT starts.

We have a huge Confluence site with many spaces and information that is not that much organized so the best ways to find something is searching, not browsing. Many times a search result looks promising, but when I select that page I see that it is not what I was looking for. Then I have to go up to the search field and rewrite the whole search phrase again. Maybe change it somewhat. That is quite combersome and annoying. I would like to have the latest search phrases easily acessible at the tip och my fingers, just like when you click into the Google search field. Maybe a section just above "RECENTLY VISITED"? I know that I can click "Advanced search", but that is not as intuative. I'm an optimist, so I hope to find the right page at once, I don't plan for it to be a struggle...

 

Please consider this request. You don't have to make the feature compulsary, you could make it activate if a feature flag is enabled in the configuration. I believe many will love it!

 

/Björn

h3. Issue Summary

In certain conditions, deleting all future occurrences of an event in Team Calendar removes the event from the TC UI, however, it does not remove the event from the database. When the calendar is exported to .ics, the deleted events can still be found and are imported to external calendars such as Outlook and iCal
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Add a new event with the following steps. To reporudce the issue, it has to be exactly the following steps.
 # Head over to TC and create a new event
 # Set start date to a date in the future
 # Set end date to a date a couple of month after the start date
 # Set event to repeat weekly
 # Set end date for repeating event
 # Save event 
 !Screenshot 2021-09-24 at 18.46.51.png|thumbnail!
 # Delete event in Team Calendar with option all future instances. For this step, delete the first occurrence of the event so when you remove the event and its future instances the whole event is removed. 
   !Screenshot 2021-09-24 at 18.47.47.png|thumbnail!
 # Export Calendar to Outlook/ical

h3. Expected Results
 # The event is removed from the database i.e. AO_950DC3_TC_EVENTS table
 # The event is not found in the exported .ics file
 # The deleted event is not shown in Outlook/iCal when importing

h3. Actual Results
 # The event is removed from the Team Calendar UI 
 # The event is *not* removed from the database i.e. AO_950DC3_TC_EVENTS table
 # The event can still be found in the exported .ics file, which subsequently mens that if it was imported to Outlook or iCal, this event will be imported.

h3. Workaround

At the moment there is no workaround.
fields.summary: Deleting all future occurrences of an event in Team Calendar removes the event from the TC UI but it is not removed from the database

h3. Issue Summary

Email notifications are not sent by Confluence when a new Jira event is added to a Team Calendar embedded on a watched page.
h3. Environment
 * Confluence 7.11.2, 7.4.0, 6.13.0
 * Team Calendar 7.0.14/7.0.17
 * Jira 8.2.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Set up a mail server within Confluence.
 # Integrate Confluence with Jira via app link.
 # Create a project within Jira.
 # Create a Team Calendar within Confluence and embed the calendar within a page.
 ## Configure a _Jira Issue Dates_ event type within the calendar.
 ## Either select a project in Jira or use JQL to select a project.
 ## Select a single date type that will be used to display a given Jira issue within the calendar.
 # Set yourself as a watcher of the page.
 # Create a new issue within the appropriate project in Jira.

h3. Expected Results
 # The new issue should appear in the Team Calendar that's embedded within the Confluence page.
 # Confluence should send an email notification to the page watcher since a new event appears within the calendar.

h3. Actual Results
 # The new Jira event does render within the embedded Team Calendar (/)
 # However, no email notification is sent for this new event addition to the Team Calendar (x)

 * No errors are displayed within the mail queue.
 * No errors are recorded within the Confluence logs (even with notification debug logging enabled).

h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available.
fields.summary: Notification not sent when a new Jira event is added to a Team Calendar embedded on a watched page

h3. Issue Summary

The Label Gadget macro is creating a link to run a Jira search in the Confluence server instead of the Jira server itself. 
 For example:

*Wrong Structure created by Confluence:*

 
{code:java}
https://<CONFLUENCE-SERVER-URL>/issues/jql=project+%3D+10001+AND+labels+%3D+label01 
{code}
*Correct Structure that should be created*:

 
{code:java}
https://<JIRA-SERVER-URL>/issues/?jql=project+%3D+10001+AND+labels+%3D+label01
{code}
h3. Steps to Reproduce

In order to reproduce this, we must have a Confluence instance linked with a Jira instance with the gadget added individually with Gadget Specifications or globally with Gadget Feeds.
 # Create a page in Confluence.
 # Add the Labels Gadget to the page.
 # Configure the gadget to a Jira project that has at least one label created.
 # Save the page. 
 # Select the label that is listed in the Gadget.

h3. Expected Results

If the URL was correctly set we would access the search page in Jira like in the image below:
 !correctpage.png|width=300,height=191!
h3. Actual Results

We get a 404 error because the URL created is using the Confluence base URL to execute an operation that was supposed to be run with the Jira base URL.


 !404-Error.png|width=340,height=85!
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no automated workaround for this behavior. 
 In order to see the results the user must change the URL manually in the browser
fields.summary: Labels Gadget is leading the user to the wrong URL

h3. Environment

1. Create a page with a title containing special character or cyrillic characters such as :

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Confluence Server and Data Center currently do not track or restrict specific terms that an organization might want to avoid, such as curse words or culturally inappropriate language.

A few examples: "Whitelist/Blacklist", "Master/Slave", "Blackout", "Man Hours" etc.
h3. Suggested Solution

Implement a new Feature to better control the usage of specific terms and suggest alternatives:
 # Create a list of terms to be watched
 # Provide a field for alternative terms to be suggested (Eg.: "Whitelist" can be changed to "Allowlist" instead)
 # Automatically scan new content (create and update) for the listed terms (from Pages, Blog Posts, Questions, Calendar Events etc)
 # Add Inline comments on top of the listed terms providing alternatives (Eg.: highlight a new "Whitelist" entry and add an Inline comment mentioning "Please consider using 'Allowlist' instead")
 # Create a Job to scan existing content and search for the listed terms
 # Provide a structured report based on the scanned results with metadata (Eg.: term used, number of times it is used, content where the term appears, link to the content, etc.)
 # Create a banned terms list and avoid content to be saved if it contains any of those.

h3. Workaround

1. Create reports based on SQL queries to be ran against the Confluence database to find those terms and provide related content metadata, such as:
{code:sql}
select * from BODYCONTENT 
WHERE body LIKE '%Whitelist%';
{code}
The results can be joined to the CONTENT table by using the corresponding *contentid*s for better results (Title, Creator, Creation Date etc).

2. Implement scripts via third-party Apps / Plugins (such as Adaptavist's [ScriptRunner for Confluence|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1215215/scriptrunner-for-confluence?hosting=datacenter&tab=overview]) to scan for terms and suggest alternatives and/or report their usage to admins, as described on [Adaptavist ScriptRunner - Event Listeners |https://scriptrunner.adaptavist.com/6.5.3/confluence/listeners.html#_working_with_custom_event_listeners].
fields.summary: Better control for specific terms

Title tags are removed in macros, this leads to title elements not to be available in the macro content.

For example, this can be a problem when the macro renders an svg tag containing a title tag because the title tag (usually represented as a tooltip) will not be visible.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
The steps below are specific to a macro but other macros will be affected as well.
 # Install the "HTML for Confluence" macro
 # Add HTML code containing a title tag within an svg tag
For example:
{code:java}
<svg viewBox="0 0 20 10" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <circle cx="5" cy="5" r="4">
    <title>I'm a circle</title>
  </circle>
</svg>
{code}

h3. Expected Results
The title is visible:
!image-2021-07-27-11-02-24-333.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Actual Results
The title does not appear and, when inspecting the HTML of the page, the {{<title>}} tag is not present.

h3. Workaround
One option could be to use Asynchronous Macros (https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Answers-Developer-Questions/Asynchronous-Confluence-Macro/qaq-p/546874)

h3. Issue Summary
When using the Jira Macro and showing a description which contains square brackets, the macro generates an internal <span class=error> element.

The error value for the class attribute could be interpreted by apps as an error and be shown with an unexpected styling.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
The steps below are based on the "Scroll Word Exporter" app but this bug can affect other macros.
 # Install the "Scroll Word Exporter" app
 # Create a Jira issue with square brackets in its description
 !image-2021-07-26-16-36-07-109.png|thumbnail! 
 # On a Confluence page, add the Jira Macro and make sure that the "Description" column is visible
# Export the page by selecting the “Export to Word” option

h3. Expected Results
The generated document matches the Confluence page.

h3. Actual Results
The generated document shows an unexpected red background when opening it with Word:
 !image-2021-07-26-16-38-31-250.png|thumbnail! 

When using TextEdit or Google Docs, an additional nested cell is visible on the generated document:
 !image-2021-07-26-16-39-57-309.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
The problem is caused by an internal element ({{<span class="error">}}) surrounding the square brackets. While this is unexpected and incorrect, a workaround could be for apps to ignore this styling.
When using this option though, an issue with the Macro would not be highlighted in the resulting export.
fields.summary: When using the Jira Macro and showing a description which contains square brackets, the macro generates an internal <span class=error> element

h3. Problem Definition

Confluence Administrators often need to manage user licenses in order to free up available seats. Currently there's no easy & streamlined process to achieve this goal.

PS: Atlassian recommends *Disabling* users (instead of Deleting them) as it keeps the original user's content while reducing the number of used seats. Also, if needed, those accounts can be re-enabled.

Reference: [Confluence - Delete or Disable Users|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/delete-or-disable-users-138318.html].
h3. Suggested Solution

Implement a *'License Cleanup'* menu that provides a few tools:
 # Find users that haven't logged in to Confluence in 3 months (suggested by default, custom value also possible)
 # Display results in a structured way (username, last login date, created date etc.)
 # Mention the number of licenses that can be freed up immediately
 # Export results in PDF, CSV and possibly other formats
 # 'Disable All' button to bulk Disable users listed in (2) immediately
 # Define thresholds for when available seats are reaching the limit
 # Implement threshold warnings (via interface, email etc.)

Also possible to improve the Unauthorized login screen to specifically mention the user has been disabled and the Confluence Administrator needs to be contacted (something like "Your account has been disabled, please reach out to admin@charlie.com to re-enable it").
h3. Workaround

1. Purchase a license with a higher user tier (eg.: 500 users -> 1.000 users)
 2. Use database queries to find and disable/delete users: [How to identify inactive users in Confluence|https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/how-to-identify-inactive-users-in-confluence-214335880.html]
fields.summary: Implement 'License Cleanup' feature

fields.description:
In situations where it is desired or required to build out your Cloud infrastructure manually (as opposed to using an AWS Quick Start template or the Confluence Data Center Azure Marketplace app to deploy from) you may not initially know what number of peers will be possibly joining or their network addresses. Neither AWS nor Azure support multicast networking, an option which doesn't require a pre-existing list of peers to be defined.

AWS solves this problem with [the "aws" cluster join type|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/change-node-discovery-from-multicast-to-tcp-ip-or-aws-792297728.html] option.

(i) Azure is limited to "tcp_ip" as the only cluster join type available (which requires a list of peers to be defined in {{confluence.cfg.xml}} in the {{confluence.cluster.peers}} property).
h4. Request

Create an "azure" join type that functions like the "aws" cluster join type, is dynamic, and does not require to list all possible peers ahead of time. 
h4. Workaround

Create a subnet and DHCP pool dedicated for Confluence and list all possible IP addresses in the Confluence DHCP scope that you have dedicated for Confluence (does not have to be a large pool, 4 Confluence nodes = minimum of 4 IP address in the DHCP scope).
 * this DHCP range/subnet must be routable to the database server and shared attachments directory's host

When nodes come online, if they are configured with an IP from that range, if their {{confluence.cluster}} settings in {{confluence.cfg.xml}} define the same cluster name, and if they list each other as peers then they will join up to the same cluster and see each other as members. They will not show the other missing members as being offline, only each other as online and the cluster will not be affected by the absence of the other nodes listed in {{confluence.cluster}} settings in {{confluence.cfg.xml}} 
 * i.e. if only some and not all listed peers are not online and present, the missing ones *will not* show as offline 
 * only nodes that had joined recently *and then recently went offline* would be listed as _offline_ until they drop from the cluster altogether if they do not return
fields.summary: Request for Azure to have AWS-style Hazelcast cluster join type

h3. Issue Summary

The 'remember me' checkbox is hidden and automatically checked on a DC cluster. The user by default has a 2 week session even on an untrusted device. It will be nice to allow the admins to enforce, show or disable remember me feature.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Set up a Confluence DC cluster
 # Go to login form

h3. Expected Results

The user should be able to choose a short session on a public machine.
h3. Actual Results

There 'remember me' checkbox is hidden and automatically checked.
h3. Workaround

*Enforce and hide 'remember me':*

This behaviour is enforced on a DC cluster. End users by default have a shared Seraph long session between nodes.
 # Stop Confluence
 # Go to Confluence installation directory
 # Locate the {{<CONFLUENCE-INSTALLATION>/confluence/login.vm}} file and make a backup copy
 # Edit the file
 # Locate the following section of code:
{code:java}
#if ($action.shouldRememberMeCheckboxBeOmitted())
    <input type="hidden" name="os_cookie" value="true"/>
#else
    #bodytag( "Component" "label='remember.accesskey'" "name='os_cookie'" "value='false'" "theme='aui'" "template='onofflist.vm'") #end
#end
{code}

 # Modify the above code as follows
{code:java}
<input type="hidden" name="os_cookie" value="true"/> 
{code}

 # Save the file and restart Confluence
 # Repeat the above steps each time you install a new version of Confluence

*Show 'remember me':*

The is the default behaviour in a non-clustered instance. This allows the end user to decide to have a Tomcat short session or Seraph long session but the user may need to login in again when hitting a new node.
 * Set [System Property|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/configuring-system-properties-168002854.html] "[cluster.login.rememberme.enabled|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/recognized-system-properties-190430.html#RecognizedSystemProperties-cluster.login.rememberme.enabled]" to true
 * This system property has no effect in standalone Confluence.

*Disable and hide 'remember me':*

Disable the automatic remember me on DC clusters, this allows the end user to decide to have a Tomcat short session or Seraph long session but the user may need to login in again on a new node.
 # Stop Confluence
 # Go to Confluence installation directory
 # Locate the {{<CONFLUENCE-INSTALLATION>/confluence/login.vm}} file and make a backup copy
 # Edit the file
 # Locate the following section of code:
{code:java}
#if ($action.shouldRememberMeCheckboxBeOmitted())
    <input type="hidden" name="os_cookie" value="true"/>
#else
    #bodytag( "Component" "label='remember.accesskey'" "name='os_cookie'" "value='false'" "theme='aui'" "template='onofflist.vm'") #end
#end
{code}

 # Modify the above code as follows
{code:java}
<input type="hidden" name="os_cookie" value="false"/> 
{code}

 # Save the file and restart Confluence
 # Repeat the above steps each time you install a new version of Confluence

h3. Note: 

Bitbucket Server has implemented it already [https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/configuration-properties-776640155.html]
{quote}Controls whether remember-me authentication is disabled, always performed or only performed when a checkbox is checked on the login form. The 'Remember my login' checkbox is only displayed when set to 'optional'. Possible values are:
 * {{always}}

No checkbox, remember-me cookie is always generated on successful login.
 * {{optional}}

Checkbox is displayed on login form. Remember-me cookie is only generated when checkbox is checked.
 * {{never}}

Remember-me authentication is disabled completely.
{quote}
fields.summary: Make the 'remember me' feature configurable

h3. Issue Summary
Presence of large text files (10+Mb) having lots of escapable/html data (characters such as *{{<, >, \, /, |, &}}* etc.) will significantly slow down indexing to the extent that it would appear to have stalled.
However, [thread dumps|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/generating-a-thread-dump-externally-182158040.html] will show indexing thread(s):
* in a runnable state (*{{java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE}}*), and
* constantly executing *{{com.atlassian.confluence.util.HtmlEntityEscapeUtil.unEscapeHtmlEntities}}* code

(i) *Note*: Only large *text files* containing *significant quantities* of *special/escapable characters* will cause the problem.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
(Tested on Confluence 7.4.[1-8] and 7.12)
# Attach a 10+Mb *{{\*.txt}}* file containing lots of SQL-queries/HTML-source/special-characters to a Confluence page
# Wait for the scheduled background indexing job (*{{Caesium}}* thread) to pick up the newly attached data, or rebuild indexes (via _Confluence Administration > Content Indexing > Search Index > Rebuild_)

h3. Expected Results
* When the scheduled background *{{Caesium}}* indexing thread picks up the data, indexing should finish in reasonable time, and 0 pending data should be shown in _Confluence Administration > Content Indexing > Queue Contents_
* When a one-time/on-demand reindexing job is manually triggered, *{{Indexer}}* thread(s) should finish in reasonable time, and show 100% re-index task completion 

h3. Actual Results
* When the scheduled background *{{Caesium}}* indexing thread picks up the data:
** it spends an inordinate amount of time processing payload from the file and is extremely slow in getting to the remaining indexable items (visible as the steadily increasing _Number of items in queue_ metric under _Confluence Administration > Content Indexing > Queue Contents_).
Thread dumps will show the *{{Caesium}}* thread in the following state:
{code:bash|title=thread dump excerpt of a "Caesium-1-N" thread}
"Caesium-1-1" #373 daemon prio=5 os_prio=0 tid=0x000001a95b71d000 nid=0x380c runnable [0x000000361d4fd000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
	at java.lang.String.indexOf(String.java:1769)
	at java.lang.String.indexOf(String.java:1718)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.util.HtmlEntityEscapeUtil.unEscapeHtmlEntities(HtmlEntityEscapeUtil.java:388)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.search.lucene.extractor.HtmlEntityFilterExtractor.addFields(HtmlEntityFilterExtractor.java:13)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.plugin.descriptor.ExtractorModuleDescriptor$BackwardsCompatibleExtractor.addFields(ExtractorModuleDescriptor.java:39)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.internal.index.lucene.LuceneContentExtractor.lambda$extract$0(LuceneContentExtractor.java:68)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.internal.index.lucene.LuceneContentExtractor$$Lambda$2093/1823784346.accept(Unknown Source)
	...
{code}
\\
\\
* When a one-time/on-demand reindexing job is manually triggered:
** *{{Indexer: N}}* thread(s) spend(s) inordinate amount of time processing payload from the file, giving the appearance that indexing is stuck at a specific completion percentage (sometimes for hours).
Thread dumps will show *{{Indexer}}* thread(s) in the following state:
{code:bash|title=thread dump excerpt of an "Indexer: N" thread}
"Indexer: 1" #369 daemon prio=5 os_prio=0 cpu=51468.75ms elapsed=51.59s allocated=54757K defined_classes=45 tid=0x000002a704504800 nid=0x1108 runnable  [0x000000bdaf7fd000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
	at com.atlassian.confluence.util.HtmlEntityEscapeUtil.unEscapeHtmlEntities(HtmlEntityEscapeUtil.java:390)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.search.lucene.extractor.HtmlEntityFilterExtractor.addFields(HtmlEntityFilterExtractor.java:13)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.plugin.descriptor.ExtractorModuleDescriptor$BackwardsCompatibleExtractor.addFields(ExtractorModuleDescriptor.java:39)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.internal.index.lucene.LuceneContentExtractor.lambda$extract$0(LuceneContentExtractor.java:68)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.internal.index.lucene.LuceneContentExtractor$$Lambda$2457/0x0000000102b61c40.accept(Unknown Source)
	...
{code}
\\
\\
* The behavior can also be observed by performing the following steps:
## [set the log level|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/configuring-logging-181535215.html] of the package *{{com.atlassian.bonnie.search.extractor}}* and *{{com.atlassian.confluence.internal.index.lucene}}* to *{{DEBUG}}*
## track indexing progress by looking at the application logs
## note those text files which cause long intervals in between the printing of the following two extractors (*{{indexme10mb.txt}}* in this example):
{code:bash|title=atlassian-confluence.log with indexing related DEBUG lines}
# PAYLOAD PASSED TO HtmlEntityFilterExtractor
2021-07-05 16:00:08,327 DEBUG [Indexer: 1] [internal.index.lucene.LuceneContentExtractor] lambda$extract$0 Adding fields to document for Attachment: indexme10mb.txt v.1 (360471) admin using BackwardsCompatibleExtractor wrapping com.atlassian.confluence.search.lucene.extractor.HtmlEntityFilterExtractor@707d0516 (confluence.extractors.core:htmlEntitiesFilterExtractor)
# ~600 SECONDS GAP
# PAYLOAD PASSED TO TitleExtractor
2021-07-05 16:10:42,266 DEBUG [Indexer: 1] [internal.index.lucene.LuceneContentExtractor] lambda$extract$0 Adding fields to document for Attachment: indexme10mb.txt v.1 (360471) admin using BackwardsCompatibleExtractor wrapping com.atlassian.confluence.search.lucene.extractor.TitleExtractor@1df9ba4a (confluence.extractors.core:titleExtractor)
{code}
(i) Occasionally, the *{{TitleExtractor}}* line may take tens of minutes/hours to get written for the indexer thread in question (*{{[Indexer: 1]}}* in the above example). 
So if the logs roll up, for a specific indexer thread processing a specific file, the *{{HtmlEntityFilterExtractor}}* and *{{TitleExtractor}}* lines could exist in different log files.

h3. Workaround
Currently, the only workaround is to upload zipped/compressed versions of the problematic text files:
# Identify and download copies of the the problematic text files from Confluence.
As outlined previously, to identify problematic text files:
** set *{{com.atlassian.bonnie.search.extractor}}* and *{{com.atlassian.confluence.internal.index.lucene}}* to *{{DEBUG}}* before a reindexing attempt, and then note down those text files which have long intervals in between the printing of the *{{HtmlEntityFilterExtractor}}* and *{{TitleExtractor}}* lines in the logs
** then, collate that list with the results of this modified SQL statement taken from [this article about finding large attachments in Confluence|https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/how-to-find-the-largest-attachment-files-in-your-confluence-instance-779295552.html]:
{code:sql|title=SQL to find all ATTACHMENTS, type = *.txt, size > = 10 Mb}
select distinct 
	c.contentid as contentid,
	c.spaceid as spaceid,
	c.title as attachmenttitle,
	u.username as uploadedby,
	co.title as pagetitle,
	(cn.longval/(1024*1024)) as filesizeinmb,
	s.spacekey as spacekey,
	s.spacename as spacename
from 	
	content as c
join user_mapping as u on u.user_key = c.creator
join content as co on c.pageid = co.contentid
join spaces as s on c.spaceid=s.spaceid
join contentproperties as cn on cn.contentid = c.contentid
where 	
	c.contenttype = 'ATTACHMENT' and c.title like '%.txt'
	and cn.longval is not null
	and (cn.longval/(1024*1024)) >= 10
order by (cn.longval/(1024*1024)) desc;
{code}
{code:sql|title=Query for Oracle}
select distinct 
	c.contentid as contentid,
	c.spaceid as spaceid,
	c.title as attachmenttitle,
	u.username as uploadedby,
	co.title as pagetitle,
	(cn.longval/(1024*1024)) as filesizeinmb,
	s.spacekey as spacekey,
	s.spacename as spacename
from 	
	content c
join user_mapping u on u.user_key = c.creator
join content co on c.pageid = co.contentid
join spaces s on c.spaceid=s.spaceid
join contentproperties cn on cn.contentid = c.contentid
where 	
	c.contenttype = 'ATTACHMENT' and c.title like '%.txt'
	and cn.longval is not null
	and (cn.longval/(1024*1024)) >= 10
order by (cn.longval/(1024*1024)) desc;
{code}
(i) *Note*: As mentioned before, only *text files* containing *significant quantities* of *special/escapable characters* are to be considered.
# After the problematic text files have been identified, compress the downloaded copies (using any compression utility) and re-upload them.
# Purge the original *{{\*.txt}}* files from the instance.
fields.summary: Extremely slow indexing, thread dumps show HtmlEntityFilterExtractor busy processing payload from large (10+Mb) text files

h3. Issue Summary

User deletion from Crowd end does not remove the entries from User_mapping table in Confluence. However, the data is deleted from cwd_user table and user in not shown in Users in Confluence UI
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a Crowd user directory (RW or Readonly) and connect with Confluence
 # Create a user in Crowd and synch it with Confluence. The user will be created in Confluence and data will be populated in cwd_user and user_mapping table along with other tables.
 # Delete the user from Crowd and synchronise. The user will be deleted from Crowd, Confluence , cwd_user table but the data(username and lower_username) will remain as the username. When we delete an internal user, the value of username and lower_username changes to user-key for that particular user.
 # When I deleted the user in Crowd, the user_mapping table looks like below  !image-2021-07-11-20-42-22-124.png|width=340,height=28!

h3. Expected Results

When user is deleted, the value of username and lower_username should change to user-key for that particular user. The behaviour of user deletion should be same for local user and crowd user in Confluence.
h3. Actual Results

The user will be deleted from Crowd, Confluence , cwd_user table but the data(username and lower_username) will remain as the username. Due to this issue, when a customer creates a user with same username in Crowd (after the older one was deleted), since the username and lowerusername values still exists in Confluence for the old user, the content of old user will be shown in the activity/history for the new user which is seen as a security flaw by mu customer. Let's say the old user had name as Mark Elford and username marke and new user has name Mark Entinckap and same username marke, the content history of Mark Elford will be shown for Mark Entinckap
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: User deletion from Crowd end does not remove the entries from User_mapping table

h3. Issue Summary

A failed page move between spaces can break attachments on a page when the files themselves are moved to the new space's location in the [attachment hierarchy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/hierarchical-file-system-attachment-storage-704578486.html] and the database transaction is rolled back for any reason. This results in the page still being in the same space it always was while the attachments are now broken due to them being in the wrong space's folder in the attachments directory.

If the user re-tries the failed move operation, according to {{confluence-core/confluence/src/java/com/atlassian/confluence/pages/persistence/dao/filesystem/HierarchicalMultiStreamAttachmentDataFileSystem.java}} the directory will be appended with "{{moved_out_of_the_way}}" at the end of the attachment directory's name to avoid a conflict with the folder that is being moved from the old space to this new space. Unfortunately, this means that the contents are not merged and any files that were already moved in the first move will continue to be unavailable even though the subsequent page move succeeds.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Move a page with attachments between spaces and have it fail where the attachments are partially moved to the new space and some are left behind
 ** these attachments that were moved already will appear broken on the page now
 # Re-try the move operation, the 2nd time it succeeds but the broken attachments persist even though the page has completed its move to the new space on the 2nd try

h3. Expected Results

The contents of the directories will be merged so any missing attachments will be restored now that the page's attachment directories have been re-combined. 
h3. Actual Results

The folder that is first written to the new space's location will be appended with "{{moved_out_of_the_way}}" and any attachments in it will remain to be broken on the page even after the page is successfully moved to the new space.

Example:
{noformat}
<attachment_dir>/ver003/61/224/1474561/161/179/1179661/<attachmentID_folders>/<version_files>
{noformat}
and
{noformat}
<attachment_dir>/ver003/61/224/1474561/161/179/1179661_moved_out_of_the_way/<attachmentID_folders>/<version_files>
{noformat}
Will both be present side-by-side.
h3. Workaround

The [Missing Attachments Script|https://bitbucket.org/atlassianlabs/confluence-support-fix-missing-attachments] can find the attachments even if they are in folder that has been appended with "{{moved_out_of_the_way}}", run this script on demand to search for and recover missing attachments if they can be located in another location within the attachments directory.
fields.summary: Re-trying a failed space page move does not merge missing attachments

h3. Issue Summary

On Confluence application link creation is not possible once we delete an existing application link
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 * Create server spaces on Confluence.
 * Create the application link from Confluence to Jira or any other application
 * Check queries:
{code:java}
SELECT bandanaid, bandanacontext, bandanakey, bandanavalue FROM public.bandana where bandanakey like 'applinks.local%' {code}

 * The result from above query should return empty.
 * Delete the applink above
 * Rerun the SQL above. Now, we should see the number of rows should match with number of Global Spaces on confluence and with values:
{code:java}
applinks.local.${SPACEKEY}.confluence_space.linked.entities and value <list/>{code}

h3. Expected Results

we should see the number of rows should match with number of Global Spaces on confluence and with values from the below query:
{code:java}
applinks.local.${SPACEKEY}.confluence_space.linked.entities and value <list/>{code}


h3. Actual Results

Number of rows will not match with the number of Global Spaces on Confluence and as a result the new application link won't get created before the request times out.


h3. Workaround

 Currently there is no known workaround for this behaviour.

fields.description:
As an administrator performing site migration or backup tasks, I would like to be able to select a number of spaces and then export all of them to XML at once. I would thus like to be able to export multiple spaces at the same time, whether it be 2, 5, 50, or more spaces.

Currently, Confluence does not have a bulk space export method, but there are old APIs which service this: https://developer.atlassian.com/server/confluence/confluence-json-rpc-apis/ details a method to perform space export using deprecated RPC APIs, but this is not a contemporary way to perform the same task. Similarly, while there are third party tools which leverage these same older APIs, there is nothing in the front end which allows for bulk space exporting.
fields.summary: Add bulk space export to Confluence from GUI

h3. Issue Summary
* While changing the context path of Confluence in the {{server.xml}} file, the {{confluence.cfg.xml}} file won't update its {{confluence.webapp.context.path}} to the updated value.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a context path in the {{server.xml}} file, for example, {{/confluence}} in server.xml and add the same value to the {{confluence.webapp.context.path}} parameter in the {{confluence.cfg.xml}} file;
# After starting Confluence with it, change the context path in the {{server.xml}} to a different value, for example {{conf}}.
# Restart Confluence

h3. Expected Results
* The {{confluence.webapp.context.path}} property will reflect the change made to the context path;

h3. Actual Results
* The {{confluence.webapp.context.path}} keeps the old context path value;

h3. Workaround
# Edit the {{confluence.webapp.context.path}}, updating it with the new context path value
# Save the changes made to the {{confluence.cfg.xml}} file
# Restart Confluence

h3. Notes
* This affects directly the Clustering screen on the Administration section of Confluence. Its URL uses the {{confluence.webapp.context.path}} parameter to build their path and, if the {{confluence.webapp.context.path}} parameter is outdated in relation the context path, the UI will break.
fields.summary: confluence.cgf.xml doesn't update the context path value
